{{Infobox single | Name = 9 Crimes | Cover = | Artist = [[Damien Rice]] | from Album = [[9 (Damien Rice album)|9]] | B-side = "The Rat Within the Grain" | Released = 27 November 2006 | Format = [[Music download|Digital download]], [[Gramophone record|7" vinyl]] | Recorded = 2005 |Genre= [[Indie rock]] | Length = 3:39 | Label = Heffa, [[14th Floor Records|14th Floor]] | Writer = Damien Rice{{cite web | last = | first = | title = Damien Rice - 9 Crimes -austriancharts.at | url=http://austriancharts.at/showitem.asp?interpret=Damien+Rice&titel=9+Crimes&cat=s | accessdate = 2008-10-20}} | Producer = Damien Rice | Certification = | Last single = "[[Unplayed Piano]]"
(2005) | This single = '''"9 Crimes"'''
(2006) | Next single = "[[Rootless Tree]]"
(2007) }} "'''9 Crimes'''" is the first single from the album ''[[9 (Damien Rice album)|9]]'' by [[Damien Rice]]. This song features additional vocals from [[Lisa Hannigan]] as do the rest of the songs on the album. The [[Gramophone record|7" single]] is pressed on clear-colored vinyl and comes with a fold-out poster. ==Music video== The single's video was directed by [[Jamie Thraves]]. The video is very reminiscent of the classic short film, ''[[The Red Balloon]]''. ==Track listing== *'''7" vinyl'''{{cite web | last = | first = | title = Damien Rice | url=http://www.damienrice.com/music.php?ref=139 | accessdate = 2008-10-20}} # "9 Crimes" - 3:39 # "The Rat Within the Grain" - 2:53 ==Appearances in other media== *"9 Crimes" was featured during the episode "[[From a Whisper to a Scream]]" on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[medical drama]] ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]''.{{cite web | publisher = CNET Networks | url = http://www.tv.com/greys-anatomy/from-a-whisper-to-a-scream/episode/899403/trivia.html | title = Grey's Anatomy - From A Whisper to a Scream - Music Featured in this Episode | date = no date |accessdate = June 3, 2007 }} *"9 Crimes" was featured at the end of fourth episode of season two of the American television series ''[[Jericho (2006 TV series)|Jericho]]''.{{cite web|url=http://jericho.wetpaint.com/page/Music+of+Jericho |title=Music of Jericho - Jericho |publisher=Jericho.wetpaint.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-06}} *"9 Crimes" was played during the obsequies of [[Germany national football team|German]] [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] [[Robert Enke]] ([[Hannover 96]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/0,1518,661359,00.html |title=Article in the news magazine "Der Spiegel" |publisher=Spiegel.de |date= |accessdate=2011-09-06}} *"9 Crimes" was sampled in the [[Weerd Science]] track "Infinity". *"9 Crimes" was used in a brief scene in ''[[Shrek the Third]]'', and is available on [http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0413267/soundtrack the official soundtrack]. *The original demo of "9 Crimes" by Damien Rice was used in an episode of ''[[True Blood]]'' called "9 Crimes".http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1484331/ ==Charts== {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- !Chart (2006−14) !Peak
position |- {{Singlechart|Austria|57|artist=Damien Rice|song=9 Crimes|rowheader=true|accessdate=17 November 2013}} |- {{Singlechart|Flanders|7|artist=Damien Rice|song=9 Crimes|rowheader=true|accessdate=17 November 2013}} |- {{Singlechart|Wallonia|33|artist=Damien Rice|song=9 Crimes|rowheader=true|accessdate=17 November 2013}} |- {{Singlechart|Germany2|61|artist=Damien Rice|song=9 Crimes|rowheader=true|accessdate=17 November 2013}} |- {{Singlechart|Ireland|14|artist=Damien Rice|song=9 Crimes|rowheader=true|accessdate=17 November 2013|year=2006|week=49}} |- {{Singlechart|Dutch100|39|artist=Damien Rice|song=9 Crimes|rowheader=true|accessdate=17 November 2013}} |- {{Singlechart|Switzerland|56|artist=Damien Rice|song=9 Crimes|rowheader=true|accessdate=17 November 2013}} |- {{Singlechart|UK|29|artist=Damien Rice|song=9 Crimes|rowheader=true|accessdate=17 November 2013|date=2006-12-09}} |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{MetroLyrics song|damien-rice|9-crimes}} {{Damien Rice}} [[Category:Damien Rice songs]] [[Category:Lisa Hannigan songs]] [[Category:2006 singles]] {{2000s-pop-single-stub}}

(2014) | Next album = | Misc = {{Singles | Name = My Favourite Faded Fantasy | Type = studio | Single 1 = [[My Favourite Faded Fantasy (song)|My Favourite Faded Fantasy]] | Single 1 date = 8 September 2014 | Single 2 = [[I Don't Want To Change You]] | Single 2 date = 24 September 2014 }} }} '''''My Favourite Faded Fantasy''''' is the third studio album by Irish singer, songwriter and producer [[Damien Rice]]. The album is expected to be released on 10 November marking eight years since the release of his previous album ''[[9 (Damien Rice album)|9]]''. ==Track listing== {{Track listing | all_writing = [[Damien Rice]] | title1 = [[My Favourite Faded Fantasy (song)|My Favourite Faded Fantasy]] | note1 = | length1 = 6:11 | title2 = It Takes a Lot To Know a Man | note2 = | length2 = | title3 = The Greatest Bastard | note3 = | length3 = 5:04 | title4 = [[I Don't Want To Change You]] | note4 = | length4 = 5:26 | title5 = Colour me In | note5 = | length5 = | title6 = The Box | note6 = | length6 = | title7 = Trusty and True | note7 = | length7 = | title8 = Long Long Way | note8 = | length8 = }} {{tracklist |headline = Limited Edition Box Set Bonus Track |collapsed = yes |title9 = Camarillas |length9 = }} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} * {{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/my-favourite-faded-fantasy/id915616196|title=iTunes Music}} {{Damien Rice}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{DEFAULTSORT:My Favourite Faded Fantasy}} [[Category:2014 albums]] [[Category:Damien Rice albums]] [[Category:English-language albums]] [[Category:Upcoming albums]]

rev2 = [[The Guardian]] | rev2Score = {{Rating|2|5}}{{cite news|author=Mat Snow |url=http://music.guardian.co.uk/rock/reviews/story/0,,1937833,00.html |title=CD: Damien Rice, 9 Crimes | Music | The Guardian |publisher=Music.guardian.co.uk |date= 3 November 2006|accessdate=2 September 2011 |location=London|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080614070241/http://music.guardian.co.uk:80/rock/reviews/story/0,,1937833,00.html|archivedate=14 June 2008}} | rev3 = [[The Independent]] | rev3Score = {{Rating|2|5}}{{cite news|url=http://enjoyment.independent.co.uk/music/reviews/article1949042.ece |title=Ford Fiesta overtakes VW Golf as Europe's favorite drive – Motoring, Life & Style – The Independent |publisher=Enjoyment.independent.co.uk |date=20 April 2010 |accessdate=2 September 2011 |location=London |first=Andy |last=Gill}} | rev4 = [[The New York Times]]{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/20/arts/music/20choi.html | work=The New York Times | title=New CDs | date=20 November 2006}} | rev4Score = n/a | rev5 = [[Okayplayer]] | rev5Score = {{Rating|3.5|5}}[http://www.okayplayer.com/reviews/index.php/weblog/more/nineteen_eighty_three1/ ] {{Wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.okayplayer.com/reviews/index.php/weblog/more/nineteen_eighty_three1/|date =20071014021636}} | rev6 = [[Pitchfork Media]] | rev6Score = (1.9/10)[http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/9641-9/ Damien Rice: 9 | Album Reviews | Pitchfork] {{Wayback|df=yes|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/9641-9/|date =20131015175137}} | rev7 = [[Q Magazine]] | rev7Score = {{Rating|4|5}}[http://www.eskimofriends.com/reviews.asp ] {{Wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.eskimofriends.com/reviews.asp|date =20100116135938}} | rev8 = [[Rolling Stone]] | rev8Score = {{Rating|3|5}}[http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/damienrice/albums/album/12133036/review/12451297/9 ] {{Wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/damienrice/albums/album/12133036/review/12451297/9|date =20091003010659}} | rev9 = [[Slant Magazine]] | rev9Score = {{Rating|3.5|5}}[http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/music_review.asp?ID=296 Music | Slant Magazine] {{Wayback|df=yes|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/music_review.asp?ID=296|date =20091030190935}} }} '''''9''''' is the second studio album by Irish singer, songwriter and producer [[Damien Rice]], released in 2006. The album was released on 3 November in Ireland, 6 November in the United Kingdom and 14 November in the US. It was followed by the single "[[9 Crimes]]", which was released on 27 November 2006. The record was certified gold in the UK. ==Background== Damien Rice had originally intended to record only one album, ''O'', but he ended up releasing ''9'' at the insistence of his record company. He later said in an interview: "Now I regret that, because I would take half the songs that are on ''9'' off. I just don't think it's good as a record as it could be".{{cite news|last=Tyaransen|first=Olaf|title=Cri de Coeur|newspaper=Hot Press Annual|date=December 2009|pages=26–31}} "Elephant" was originally titled "The Blower's Daughter Part 2". "The Blower's Daughter" is a song on Rice's first album ''[[O (Damien Rice album)|O]]''. ==Track listing== {{Track listing | all_writing = [[Damien Rice]] | title1 = [[9 Crimes]] | note1 = Contains the [[hidden track]] "[[9 Crimes]] (Demo)" in the [[pregap]] to the first CD track. It is a rough demo of "9 Crimes" with all vocals by Rice. | length1 = 3:39 | title2 = The Animals Were Gone | note2 = | length2 = 5:41 | title3 = Elephant | note3 = | length3 = 5:57 | title4 = [[Rootless Tree]] | note4 = | length4 = 4:22 | title5 = [[Dogs (Damien Rice song)|Dogs]] | note5 = | length5 = 4:11 | title6 = Coconut Skins | note6 = | length6 = 3:45 | title7 = Me, My Yoke + I | note7 = | length7 = 5:57 | title8 = Grey Room | note8 = | length8 = 5:43 | title9 = Accidental Babies | note9 = | length9 = 6:34 | title10 = Sleep Don't Weep | note10 = The song ends with 16 minutes of wine glasses and a [[Tibet]]an singing bowl played by Rice. | length10 = 21:54 | title11 = The Rat Within the Grain" | note11 = [[Bonus track]] | length11 = 2:54 }} ==Personnel== * Daisy – drawing, painting * [[Shane Fitzsimons]] – bass, [[double bass]] * [[Lisa Hannigan]] – backing vocals * [[Vyvienne Long]] – cello * [[Cora Venus Lunny]] – [[viola]], violin * [[Tom Osander]] – drums, [[glass music|glasses]] * [[Damien Rice]] – [[clarinet]], [[Rhodes piano|Fender Rhodes]], guitar, percussion, piano, production, [[singing bowl]]s, vocals, [[wurlitzer]] * Joel Shearer – electric guitar ==Critical reaction== The album was released to mixed critical and fan reaction. ''[[NME]]'' gave the album 4/10, describing it as "[[IKEA]] rock". ''[[Hot Press]]'' wrote "If Rice really was a nervous wounded-wing, there's no way he'd skirt as close to Nick Drake comparisons as he does on 'The Animals Are Gone'", and, in a reference to the 'noise' preceding the first track, "there's another noise that can be made out faintly but distinctly — the sound of the [[David Gray (musician)|Grays]], [[Ray LaMontagne|LaMontagnes]], [[Jack Johnson (musician)|Johnsons]] and the [[James Blunt|Blunts]] of this world breaking their pencil tips on their jotters in sheer envy and frustration.''" Both ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]'' and ''[[Q (magazine)|Q]]'' gave the album 4/5. ''[[The Sunday Times'']] made it their 'Album of the Week'. It was [[People Magazine]]'s Critic Choice in November 2006. ==Sales chart performance== The album reached number 4 in the [[UK Albums Chart]].{{cite web|url=http://www.everyhit.com |title=UK Top 40 Chart Archive, British Singles & Album Charts |publisher=everyHit.com |date=16 March 2000 |accessdate=2 September 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110723023423/http://www.everyhit.com/| archivedate= 23 July 2011 | deadurl= no}} In the US, it was on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] for 10 weeks, peaking on its debut at #22.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} ==Charts== {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- !Chart (2006) !Peak
position |- {{Albumchart|Australia|33|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{Albumchart|Flanders|14|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{Albumchart|Wallonia|53|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{Albumchart|Netherlands|20|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{Albumchart|France|86|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{Albumchart|Germany3|87|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{Albumchart|Ireland|1|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|year=2006|week=45|rowheader=true}} |- !scope="row"|Italian Albums ([[FIMI]]){{cite web|url=http://www.fimi.it/main/chart_id/86|publisher=[[Federation of the Italian Music Industry]]|language=Italian|accessdate=2 November 2013|title=Classifiche - Archivio - Classifica settimanale WK 46 (dal 06-11-2006 al 12-11-2006)|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20131103075930/http://www.fimi.it/main/chart_id/86|archivedate=3 November 2013}} |33 |- {{Albumchart|Norway|8|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{Albumchart|Spain|94|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{Albumchart|Sweden|24|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{Albumchart|Switzerland|48|artist=Damien Rice|album=9|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{albumchart|UK|4|artist=Damien Rice|accessdate=2 November 2013|rowheader=true}} |- {{albumchart|Billboard200|22|artist=Damien Rice|artistid={{BillboardID|Damien Rice}}|rowheader=true|accessdate=2 November 2013}} |} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/damien-rice/24400|title=Damien Rice reveals new album|date=20 September 2006|work=NME |location=UK |accessdate=11 February 2011|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20130701064720/http://www.nme.com:80/news/damien-rice/24400|archivedate=1 July 2013}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.damienrice.com/music/discography/cd/default.aspx?albumId=853f0938-36ea-4633-8283-5581fd0407d8|title=9|publisher=damienrice.com|accessdate=11 February 2011|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120428200114/http://www.damienrice.com:80/music/discography/cd/default.aspx?albumId=853f0938-36ea-4633-8283-5581fd0407d8|archivedate=28 April 2012}} {{Damien Rice}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{DEFAULTSORT:9 (Damien Rice Album)}} [[Category:2006 albums]] [[Category:Damien Rice albums]] [[Category:English-language albums]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox album | Name = O | Type = studio | Artist = [[Damien Rice]] | Cover = Damien Rice O album cover.jpg | Released = 1 February 2002 | Recorded = 2001 | Genre = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[indie rock]], [[Acoustic music|acoustic rock]] | Length = 61:27 | Language = [[English language|English]] | Label = [[14th Floor Records|14th Floor]] (Ireland/UK)
Vector (USA) | Producer = [[Damien Rice]] | Last album = | This album = '''''O'''''
(2002) | Next album = ''[[B-Sides (Damien Rice album)|B-Sides]]''
(2004)| | Misc = {{Singles | Name = O | Type = studio | Single 1 = The Blower's Daughter | Single 1 date = September 2001 | Single 2 = [[Cannonball (Damien Rice song)|Cannonball]] | Single 2 date = 2002 | Single 3 = [[Volcano (Damien Rice song)|Volcano]] | Single 3 date = 2002 }} }} {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[Allmusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|4.5|5}} [{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r636131|pure_url=yes}} link] | rev2 = ''[[The Guardian]]'' | rev2Score = {{Rating|4|5}} [http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2002/aug/09/popandrock.artsfeatures2 link] | rev3 = [[Pitchfork Media]] | rev3Score = (5.4/10) [http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/6898-o/ link] | rev4 = ''[[Q magazine|Q]]'' | rev4Score = {{Rating|4|5}} | rev5 = ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' | rev5Score = {{Rating|3|5}} [http://www.rollingstone.com/artists/damienrice/albums/album/291401/review/5941574/o link] | rev6 = ''[[Slant Magazine|Slant]]'' | rev6Score = {{Rating|5|5}} [http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/music_review.asp?ID=296 link] | rev7 = [[Sputnikmusic]] | rev7Score = {{Rating|4.5|5}} [http://www.sputnikmusic.com/album.php?albumid=244 link] | rev8 = ''[[Stylus Magazine]]'' | rev8Score = (C) [http://www.stylusmagazine.com/reviews/damien-rice/o.htm link] | rev9 = [[Openheartzoo]] | rev9Score = {{Rating|4|5}} [http://openheartzoo.com/reviews/#rice link] }} '''''O''''' is [[Damien Rice]]'s first [[studio album]], originally released on 1 February 2002, in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] and in the [[United Kingdom]]. The album is dedicated to Rice's friend [[Mic Christopher]], who died of a head injury in 2001. Rice wanted to make the album without the backing of a major [[record label]], believing if he signed such a deal it would compromise his future work, forcing him to move in directions he did not wish to.{{cite web|url=http://www.cluas.com/music/albums/damienrice.htm|title=Album Reviews - Damien Rice 'O'|publisher=CLUAS|year=2002|accessdate=2009-03-05}} The video for the song "Volcano" charted in the United States on [[VH1]]'s Top 20 Video countdown in October 2003.{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m4PRN/is_2003_Oct_8/ai_n27660648|title=VH1's Music Radar; Wed., October 8 - Tues., October 14, 2003|date=2003-10-08|publisher=Find Articles|accessdate=2008-07-05}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} ==Track listing== {{track listing | all_writing = [[Damien Rice]] | title1 = Delicate | length1 = 5:12 | title2 = Volcano | length2 = 4:38 | title3 = The Blower's Daughter | length3 = 4:44 | title4 = [[Cannonball (Damien Rice song)|Cannonball]] | length4 = 5:10 | title5 = Older Chests | length5 = 4:46 | title6 = Amie | length6 = 4:36 | title7 = Cheers Darlin' | length7 = 5:50 | title8 = Cold Water | length8 = 4:59 | title9 = I Remember | length9 = 5:31 | title10 = Eskimo | note10 = [[Hidden track]]s "Prague" from 7:07 to 13:00, and "[[Silent Night]]" from 14:09 to 15:57, sung by Lisa Hannigan | length10 = 15:57 }} ==Release history== After the album's initial release and success, it was repackaged several times with additional material *2003 – with bonus DVD *2004 – with extra track "Cannonball" (Remix) *2004 – double album pack: ''O'' and ''[[B-Sides (Damien Rice album)|B-Sides]]'' *2005 – with extra tracks "Cannonball" (Remix) and "Unplayed Piano" ==Personnel== *[[Damien Rice]] – [[Vocals]], [[piano]], [[guitar]], [[Percussion instrument|percussion]], [[clarinet]], [[Record producer|production]] *[[Lisa Hannigan]] – [[Backing vocalist|Backing vocals]], [[lead vocals]] on "Silent Night" (hidden track), [[piano]] *[[Vyvienne Long]] – [[Cello]] *Mark Kelly – [[Electric guitar]], [[Record producer|production]] *[[Shane Fitzsimons]] – [[Bass guitar]] *[[Tom Osander]] aka Tomo – [[Percussion]], [[drums]] *Caroline Fogerty aka Caz – [[Djembe]] *Doreen Curran – [[Mezzo soprano]] *Nicholas Dodd – [[Conducting]] *[[Colm Mac Con Iomaire]] – [[Violin]] *Conor Donovan – Timpani/percussion *Jean Meunier – [[Improvisation]], piano ==Use in Other Media== *"The Blower's Daughter" was featured in the trailer for the 2004 [[Mike Nichols]] film ''[[Closer (film)|Closer]]'', as well as in the film itself.{{cite news|last=Morris|first=Wesley|title=On 'Closer' inspection, Nichols rules|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2004/12/03/on_closer_inspection_nichols_rules/|accessdate=10 June 2011|newspaper=Boston Globe|date=3 December 2004}} *"Cold Water" was featured in the 2003 film ''[[I Am David (film)|I Am David]]'', in the end credits of the 2005 film ''[[Stay (2005 film)|Stay]]'' and as well as in the opening and closing scene of ''[[The Girl in the Café]]''. In addition, it was featured in the 2010 French movie ''[[Little White Lies (2010 film)|Little White Lies]]''. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Damien Rice}} {{DEFAULTSORT:O (Damien Rice Album)}} [[Category:2002 debut albums]] [[Category:Albums produced by Damien Rice]] [[Category:Damien Rice albums]] [[Category:English-language albums]] [[Category:Vector Recordings albums]]

{{Infobox album | Name = En t'attendent | Type = studio | Artist = [[Mélanie Laurent]] | Cover = Entamelanie.jpg | Released = {{Start date|2011|05|02|df=yes}} | Genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Rock music|rock]] | Length = {{Duration|m=50|s=06}} | Label = Atmosphériques | Producer = [[Damien Rice]], Joel Shearer | This album = '''''En t'attendent'''''
(2011) | Next album = | Misc = {{Singles | Name = En t'attendent | Type = studio | Single 1 = En t'attendent | Single 1 date = {{Start date|2011|02|21|df=yes}} }} }} '''''En t'attendant''''' is the debut studio album by the French actress and singer [[Mélanie Laurent]], released on 2 May 2011 on Atmosphériques. Produced by Joel Shearer, it contains twelve songs, five of which are co-written and co-produced with the Irish [[Folk music|folk]] musician [[Damien Rice]].{{cite web|url=http://www.twentyfourbit.com/post/3689477958/melanie-laurent-enlists-damien-rice-for-debut-album|title=Mélanie Laurent Enlists Damien Rice for Debut Album|work=TwentyFourBit|date=6 March 2011|accessdate=6 September 2011}} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | total_length = 50:06 | title1 = Début | length1 = 2:40 | title2 = En t'attendant | length2 = 4:00 | title3 = Everything You're Not Supposed to Be | note3 = featuring [[Damien Rice]] | length3 = 5:31 | title4 = Circus | length4 = 4:40 | title5 = Kiss | length5 = 3:59 | title6 = Je connais | length6 = 4:41 | title7 = Pardon | length7 = 4:01 | title8 = Insomnie | length8 = 4:07 | title9 = Il fait gris | length9 = 4:52 | title10 = Uncomfortable | note10 = featuring Damien Rice | length10 = 5:49 | title11 = Papa | length11 = 3:35 | title12 = Fin | length12 = 2:11 }} ==Chart positions== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:left" ! scope="col"| Chart (2011) ! scope="col"| Peak
position |- ! scope="row"| [[Ultratop|Belgian Albums Chart (Wa)]]{{cite web|url=http://www.ultratop.be/fr/showinterpret.asp?interpret=M%E9lanie+Laurent|title=Discographie Mélanie Laurent|work=[[Ultratop]]|publisher=Hung Medien|language=French|accessdate=15 January 2013}} | style="text-align:center"| 22 |- ! scope="row"| [[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique|French SNEP Albums Chart]]{{cite web|url=http://lescharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=M%E9lanie+Laurent&titel=En+t%27attendant&cat=a|title=Mélanie Laurent – En t'attendant|work=lescharts.com|publisher=Hung Medien|language=French|accessdate=15 January 2013}} | style="text-align:center"| 35 |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:left" ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Year ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Single ! scope="col" style="width:10em" colspan="1"| Peak chart positions |- ! scope="col" style="width:2em; font-size:75%"| [[Ultratop#Ultratip|BEL]]
